Review Title: A Year of Growth and Empowerment: Reflecting on My Journey at MongoDB
Pros:
During my past year in MongoDB, I have witnessed firsthand the company's remarkable growth and expansion. And it's exciting to be part of an organization that is constantly reaching new heights. 
Here are some points that I would consider as Pros: 
1. Comprehensive training resources for new hires to ramp up the knowledge. You dont have to be an expert in database or cloud computing domain to join the company, as long as you are willing to take the challenge and keep learning. 
2. Consistent behavior exhibited by its leadership team, both internally and in public presence. 
3. MongoDB is relatively in smaller scale in my region, but it also means you will be granted more responsibilities to experience, and also experiment new process, new industry, new customers with strong support from internal teams.
4. Product-oriented approach and really care about the developer community and customer feedbacks.
Cons:
1. Sometimes in daily work, you do have to play one-man bank to take care of different tasks that might not technically "in-scope" of your role. 
2. You may need to work or have meetings in hours that not favor your timezone due to the distribution of the global team.

Review Title: Cool place to work if you are not a partner.
Pros: Everyone is amiable and helpful when you need help or learn something.
Cons:
If you work as a partner, you'll always be stuck in your position, there is no place to grow, and all the jobs that are boring or the MongoDB employees don't want to do will be allocated to you. They will always allocate good clients or interesting consulting sessions to their own team, so it's hard to learn something new or work on a cool project. 
But the most demotivating thing is the no-compete agreement with the companies that hire the partners. If you apply for any open position at MongoDB, they won't schedule an interview, even if you're one of the best partner consulting engineers in the company with an overstanding knowledge of MongoDB.

Pros:
I find High-Trust, High-Performance, Healthy Culture in the organization, more of the Values driven, where employees feel valued and respected, leading to an increase in productivity and job satisfaction. MongoDB provide the comfort that every career opportunities dreamed of:-
Employee autonomy
Employee benefits
Always there is motivation to work
Flexible hours
Timely Rewards & Recognition
Best offered compensation
Cons: Nothing i can figure out...

Review Title: Some good people, but traumatic experience
Pros:
- Competitive pay
- Decent benefits, good health insurance
- Snacks and lunch 3x/week in the office
- "Unlimited" PTO (suggested 20)
- Made friends with some coworkers
Cons:
- A VP expressed annoyance about maternity leaves in their department
- A Director referenced the terrible German leader from WWII (Glassdoor counts the name as "bad language") as a good public speaker in a team meeting in an off-the-cuff comment
- A VP was observing said meeting and stayed silent
- A Lead put words in my mouth when speaking to a PM
- A teammate was negging
- Questions you ask if you're a POC will be "forgotten," further perpetuating a stereotype
- The longer you're there, the more you get away with. MongoDB allows its oldest employees to treat others however they want, and will twist things to fit their narrative when you try to stick up for yourself.
- Your experience here will be very department and team specific.

Pros:
Good remunerations and benefits. Super diverse teams, and good work life balance.
By far, the best onboarding process that I ever experienced.
Awesome culture, and people who takes the culture seriously.
Cons: Not so flexible about work remotely anymore.

Pros: Free lunches and snacks in the office.
Cons:
The atmosphere at MongoDB is challenging, with inexperienced engineers promoted to leadership roles lacking necessary experience. There's a lack of emotional intelligence training, and communication seems belittling. It feels like a situation where individuals with inflated egos, akin to children, are managing the company. The dynamic suggests engineers and product teams dominate, while others are perceived as mere minions. Expressing new ideas is met with swift dismissal and sometimes negative labeling.

The technical program director appears unresponsive to feedback, sticking to outdated methods. Instead of fostering an open environment, she retaliates when confronted and lacks a strong engineering background. During culture amp surveys for anonymous feedback, she conducted meetings to identify contributors, even alluding to potential repercussions for her livelihood. Despite notifying HR, no actions were taken.

Pros:
+ Top-notch product 
+ Smart people 
+ Customers love the product
Cons:
+ Toxic leadership 
+ Career progression is vague 
+ Promotions based on who the boss likes 
+ High turnover rates
+ Managers promoted not based on skills but based on tenure in the company

Pros: Pretty good training. All virtual though.
Cons:
Almost all of your success will be tied to your accounts. The other piece of your success is how well you can game the system and look busy to your leader. Most leaders, especially the VP level, are former order takers at the business, who are not good when it comes to advice or sales strategies. The biggest bro culture I have ever seen, if you're not in the club, good luck. If you are, you'll get the best accounts and all of the opps from the people not in the bro club who left. 

Being an Enterprise AE here without a hot patch is about the same day-to-day and pay as an SDR.

They talk a big game about their sales process and MBA of sales, but it seems that is to get reps in the door and convince reps to stay. In my experience since, the sales org is not highly regarded externally. Take a look at all of the people who have left within the past year. I've never seen an exodus like this before.

Review Title: Bro sales culture and moving targets
Pros:
Great product
Smart teams and leaders
Cons:
Micromanaging

Intense "bro" sales culture

My comp structure changed every quarter I worked there and I didn't know my metrics for the first month of the quarter - moving target.

You're never good enough mentality - even if you hit your number every quarter, they want to know what you could have done better, why didn't you ask X questions and how can you improve next time. While that can help with self-reflection and growth, when you are never recognized for accomplishments and only pushed to reflect on what you didn't do, it can be demotivating. There needs to be a balance.

Pros: Comfortable work environment, driven engineering, honest and transparent communication
Cons: Working on open and source available code can invite unwarranted criticism which is distinct from a position that only requires work on proprietary code

Pros: Sales enablement team is pretty good- for the boot camp period- which is also pretty much exaggerated to be honest
Cons: There’s bureaucracy inside out. A lobby of people that hire people in exchange of their one month’s salary.

Pros:
- WFH
- Good compensation
- Interesting things and investment in new tools
Cons:
- Inexperienced or political middle management focused on maintaining authority and power, while not drawing the attention of senior leadership 
- Constant throwing people under the bus or assigning other people to sink or swim
- Organization is sometimes a free-for-all because of indecisiveness or avoid difficult conversations because of wanting to be friends with everyone

Pros:
Culture 
Progression opportunities
Fun and interesting
Cons: I don't have anything to say on this

Review Title: A Thriving Environment for Personal and Professional Growth
Pros: The vibe here is awesome. Everyone's super friendly and approachable. Asking questions is totally cool, and you learn heaps from your coworkers. Management keeps things running smoothly and is super organized. Our leaders are upfront about company goals, which is great. Plus, my manager is really supportive of my career growth.
Cons: Being new to the data scene, there are definitely a bunch of challenges to tackle right off the bat.

Review Title: Just be honest and say you're doing layoffs!
Pros: Great product and long standing leadership has made great decisions for the business.
Cons: The core leadership team CEO & CFO/COO remain strong but as the company grows it is has been making weak leadership hires and beginning to operate as a large company. We are seeing a lot of people leave because of this. Also the intellectual honesty is disappearing. Instead of doing lay offs like every other company in the tech space, they are having bar raising, then underperforming conversations and managing people out as a result. Feels like a way to reduce the size and operating costs of a company without having to pay people severance packages.

Pros: Great ability to earn money, lots of development
Cons: Had no life work life balance and unrealistic expectations to be in the office

Review Title: A great company to work for
Pros:
Excellent company culture
Plenty of career opportunities
Cons: Not really much. But like any other rapidly growing company it is not guaranteed that things will still be the same in a few years.

Review Title: Great company and great team. Learned a ton and thankful
Pros: Leadership is great, product is industry-leading, culture is encouraging (and challenging in a good way) and there's lot of opportunity to make good money as a sales rep. Worked here for three years and very thankful for the time. Ended my time working for the director out of Denver, who is a phenomenal rep and truly cares for his reps.
Cons: Not for the faint of heart. Not a place for reps to come coast at the end of their career. But if you put in the work you'll learn a ton and make a ton.

Review Title: Not everything is what it seems.  Think twice here.
Pros:
Ok compensation and benefits package
You will learn a lot and quickly
Growing company/industry
Cons:
Expected to be always on/available and work-life balance slowing starts to fade more and more.
Increasing workload
Numbers not people-focused. Talk alot about their values, but not sure they live these

Review Title: Great place to learn and grow
Pros:
-challenging environment
-great people
-growth opportunities if you are willing to work for it
Cons:
-growing pains
-sink or swim

Review Title: Not a good time to be working at MongoDB
Pros: It was a great place to get a technical refresh and get familiarity with cloud provider service offerings and niche database solutions.
Cons: Myself and my team had issues getting paid on Commissions. There is no transparency in the process. We had to wait over 8 months to get $20K that was contractually obligated but they failed to pay. The senior management is focused on cost-savings initiatives and cares little for the employees well being. The West Coast in particular is understaffed and way overworked. If you are female - you are paid less than your male counterparts. There is very little representation of females to men in the sales organization. People are leaving right and left due to the toxic nature of the management team. The senior management is stuck on how things were when they were individual contributors and fail to grasp how the markets, products, number of competitors and space has changed. Issues were raised to senior levels of management and HR and HR only supports the toxic managers. There is no room for growth in the role or within the division unless you want to become a Sales Rep.

Review Title: It's a good company to be with
Pros: The industry puts you in a position to learn and grow a connection across multiple tech ecosystems,
Cons: It could be daunting for those who might not passionate in tech in general

Review Title: Run away as fast as you can!
Pros: Product is excellent and the technology fit is good in current market.
Cons: Just watched a Regional Director humiliate and bully his direct report in a QBR in front of 20 of his peers. Leadership and other management in room said nothing.

Review Title: Great Product but Toxic Culture in Sales
Pros: Great culture outside of Sales, Brand Name, Workplace, Hybrid setup of work from office
Cons: 1. Sales leadership exhibits a highly toxic culture. 2. Excessive micromanagement, frequent unnecessary meetings, and round-the-clock messages from the directors. 3. Top performing Sales directors and Account Executives do not contribute to sales; instead, they manipulate the system (sfdc) to take credit and commissions for the accounts in different regions outside India. 4. The growth team is equally redundant since the product practically sells itself, resulting in the labeling of new clusters and organic growth as upsells. 5. The leadership endorses and supports these unscrupulous practices, with the exception of the new AVP in the region who might not even know of all this in detail.

Review Title: Toxic culture and bad comp plan that’s getting worse each year
Pros:
Health benefits 
Apple work devices (all provided)
Opportunity to grow your professional network
Cons: Where do I begin? This place was once pretty decent years ago, but even then it was a tough place to be from a culture and quota attainment perspective. If you’re a minority of any kind you will likely be the only one in the room if not one of a handful. Expect to be micro managed and work well over 50 hours a week if you want to be viewed as a good employee. Overly complex comp structure that only a small percentage of people actually hit. Lots of bad managers have ended up in middle management positions across sales, customer success, and sales dev. You cannot share feedback unless it’s positive but you have to subject yourself to feedback of any kind at all times. Sales org is a walking HR violation (I saw this in another review) as it’s only men who all look the same. There’s zero diversity of any kind across most regions and they refuse to acknowledge this or do anything meaningful about it. Sales execs and senior leadership leaving left and right over the past 18 months and it looks like that trend is continuing. Managers only care about the numbers and nothing more. You have no room to be person. My manager was responsible for 4 people either asking to leave their team, or who ended up quitting, and that manager is still with the company. Sales org is a good ole boys club and those who fall in line or get close to the right people will get good accounts, grace, and actual mentoring. Customer success org doesn’t seem to be much better. I’ve heard horror stories from other regions about women getting push back for wanting to take their full maternity leave or coming back after leave with all new accounts, etc. The most toxic and exhausting QBR experience with people regularly suffering from massive amounts of stress and anxiety or going to the bathroom to cry. Full of mind games. Also, no team building events besides binge drinking. If they want you gone they will push you until you just quit. Also, the pay is below the standard for sales execs now…If I can sum up this place in a few words: just a traumatizing boys club full of egos that are stuck in an echo chamber of their own beliefs.

Pros: Great training programs and culture
Cons: Depends on you manager on how well you’re start is. Most are great

Review Title: Great company but know what you're getting into
Pros: learning, growth potential, TAM is huge (lot of opportunity)
Cons: culture is a little toxic, focus only on performance, very technical product

Pros:
- Colleagues
- Working time
Cons:
- Training introduction
- Technical hc (large company need more tech role support)

Review Title: Great place to work, great role, very demanding work
Pros: - Great learning opportunities - the first two months are the most accurate manifestation of "drinking from the firehose" I have experienced in my 11-year career as an engineer. Seriously, you learn so much useful stuff. - Awesome culture. - Big company but operates in a spokes-and-hubs fashion, so each office feels like a small startup. - Generous compensation and benefits. - Sensible middle and senior management.
Cons: Consulting engineering, which is the delivering role of MongoDB's Professional Services, is a very demanding role. Customer work has somewhat strict hours - you're dedicated to a single customer on a given day and work with them until late afternoon. After that, you must collect and tidy up your detailed notes before they're sent to the customer. Long story short, 9-5 won't cut it here. This creates a tricky situation for working parents in an egalitarian relationship who wish to see their kids during the week and not offload pickup to someone else. Keep that in mind and ask your hiring manager about how flexible the daily routine is for consultants. In the first few weeks in the role, I felt a little lost and almost lost my faith in my ability to do it just because of the daily agenda.

Pros: Helped me to build and own the science of selling. Helped me to earn more than I’ve ever earned. Fantastic leadership  who are consistent and focused, great product and market fit.
Cons: It’s development heavy culture and will only fit you if you fit the specific criteria you and mongoDB have

Pros: Love the product and people. Everyone top down is super technical. 100% employees are aligned with core values of the company which is indeed the best.
Cons: Employees fully remote do not have a great internet reimbursement policy. Like in my case my home is 42.1 mile from MongoDB office and based on Austin peak hour traffic it takes close to 3hrs one way commute that makes it practically impossible. As per the policy you have to be atleast 50 miles away to be eligible.

Pros: Good pay for a graduate
Cons: Repetitive work and average coworkers

Review Title: Classic Case of Money Cannot Buy You Culture
Pros: - Competitive compensation - Benefits - Flexibility - Cross Functional team members(some of them) and Mentors(outside India) can be a delight to work with and can help you learn.
Cons: 1. Leadership hired is extremely short sighted, inexperienced and clearly in positions they are not meant to be in. 2. Mentally abusive Management with a microaggressive approach towards subordinates. Calling them out will only invite retaliation, gaslighting and whistleblower treatment. 3. Experienced folks may have to wait a long time to get meaningful work. HR Teams are equally immature with no accountability or tools to mitigate instances of workplace bias and mental harassment. 4. Women bully women - cannot generalize this as I met some inspiring people but my direct manager was a complex case of bullying, micromanagement, microaggression, false sense of authority especially towards brown women subordinates and a general lack of integrity. 5. Lack of trust, team building, acknowledgments and good morale. 6. No career planning or KPI tracking. Faulty methods of performance evaluation. 7. Poor shift hours catering to serve only the US team.

Pros: Truly trains you to be the best. Amazing Company to be apart of. The commitment to continuous learning and development is evident in the robust training programs designed to empower individuals to reach their full potential. Being part of this organization means immersing yourself in an environment that fosters innovation, collaboration, and a relentless pursuit of excellence.
Cons: Communication isn't always clear and base pay isnt that great compared to other companies with the same role.

Pros:
* Leadership is rock solid
* MongoDB is rapidly gaining market share and developer mindset
* The product roadmap is exciting with lots of great learning opportunities
* Smart people work here
Cons: The biggest issue is that MongoDB is they are no longer a startup. In fact they are a very mature company compared to what they were even 5 years ago. Pains with this now can be seen in slow moving internal processes and having to deal with the "multiple chefs in the ktichen" problem e.g. so many people are now involved in making decisions and have opinions on features/functionality that things move really slow. That said it isn't unique to MongoDB, I would think most companies of this size (over 5,000 employees) have these issues.

Review Title: Comfortably uncomfortable - this is a good thing!
Pros:
You can get out of your comfort zone, without fear of any negative feedback
You can be your authentic self
The people are just amazing
The core values align with my own values
It really is exciting to get to work here every day
The onboarding process is excellent and well paced
Cons: I honestly do not have any cons.

Pros: Culture, compensation, team, opportunities, transparency
Cons: I didnt found any cons

Review Title: Good company with great collegaues though management is opaque about their intentions
Pros: Incredibly competent colleagues and good perks.
Cons: Lack of transparency from management

Review Title: Lots of potential, lots of hard work
Pros: The company has great values that almost all employees try to embody. Huge focus on customer success and doing the right thing. The product is incredible, one of the best SaaS solutions in the market. The new wave of AI also has MongoDB uniquely positioned to capture much more of the market.
Cons: Lots of hard work, the company expects a lot from all employees. Lots of change happening that can cause confusion and competing priorities.

Pros: They invest alot in personal development and give ADR's alot of resources to understand the technology. Overall MongoDB has great MGMT and great AE's to work with.
Cons: Pay could be alot more competitive, & they dont offer RSU's.

Review Title: Excellent Organization from Culture and Career Growth
Pros:
- Excellent leader, who care about employee and want to make sure along with company every one has equal opportunity to grow
- Excellent product
Cons: - Nothing as of now.

Review Title: Great company with even greater things ahead !
Pros:
Good technology, good positioning with developers. 
Well positioned for the next AI evolution. 
Ambitious and eager to please its employees.
Cons: Too much turnover in the Sales team probably due to high pressure there, not ideal to create long term relationship with users and/or customers.

Pros: I'm in my third year in the sales organization here at MongoDB, and loving it. It's different from any sales team I've been a part of before - from the leadership quality to the development I'm getting here, it's top notch. Can't think of a better place to be right now!
Cons: The expectations and bar are set high. You will feel stretched and challenged, but it's worth it. Don't expect to be promoted after a quarter or two - the bar for promotions is high as well.

Pros: Good benefits and salary if you can work hard.
Cons: People are very intelligent and helpful in the company. Need to work hard to catch up but it pays.

Review Title: Great company- fast paced, good rewards
Pros: Solid sales process, great market presence, a lot of upside if you follow the process and target the right accounts.
Cons: sink or swim type mentality. Quick ramp and expected to hit the ground running.

Review Title: Prioritise competency (together with culture) and hire compentent leaders preferably with larger MNC experience
Pros: Friendly and open environment, cross collaboration is a key part of the culture
Cons: There are a number of senior longer tenured employees with little to none large MNC experience therefore they do not know what to do when faced with new scenarios, lack initiative, lack competency required of their level and spend too much time on detailed work. Also, a lot of time is spent obtaining employees' opinions and decisions seem driven primarily by these opinions. Trying to advocate everyone to be a leader is not effective if the staff themselves are not competent, project priorities don't seem to be mature and appraisals are more focused on encouraging preferred behaviour than actual work deliverables. Too many meetings on leadership (talking about leadership does not train one to be a leader) and rolling out raising-the-bar initiative but there are no concrete standards on what it practically means.

Pros: Lots of nice people who take pride in teamwork and like to help others. Minimal political intrigue. Not a cutthroat environment. Main product is a database. Companies stick with the same tech stack for a long time (too long), MDB will be in business for a long time.
Cons: Too many executives in the biggest job they've ever had and are in way over their heads trying to run an enterprise company. Over-promoted middle managers who don't know what they don't know and allergic to change. Homegrown systems and processes haven't scaled and many groups are behind on industry practices. Collaborative culture has big benefits but at the big price of micromanagenent, too many cooks in the kitchen, and hazy accountability.

Pros:
Very strong leadership- aren't afraid of doing the heavy lifting, always teaching and mentoring, looks out for ICs career growth
Great culture - no snaking between reps, mature workplace, very positive collab between all teams
Cons: OTE could be more competitive

Pros:
Fast promotion
Great management
Stock
Cons:
Work life balance
Targets less archievable

Pros:
No Pros of working here at all 
Total Mental torture and no support from leadership
Cons:
No Work life balance 
No Equity offered
Long working hours 
Leaders are not at all supportive as they only care about their own promotion.
No growth and low compensation

Pros: Incredible culture and team and high paying salary
Cons: I have not run into any problem while working here

Pros: Plenty of opportunity for autonomy, mastery and purpose. Smart tech, smart business, smart finance.
Cons: Fast pace and constant growth and change.

Review Title: Great Product, tech stack and Salary, BAD Work/Life balance
Pros: -- Pay is great. -- Health Benefits are great. -- Equity is ok. -- Product is solid. -- The work is exciting and the technologies used are great for experience.
Cons: -- Extremely overloaded, we pretty much work around the clock. But still pressured constantly that we must "Raise the bar". -- A large amount of employees have horrible attitudes, very rude and zero compassion. -- Priorities change daily/weekly and are in addition to fully loaded planned work. Everything is a priority and immediately pushed on you with expectation that your current "thing" will be finished as it was a commitment. -- Not hiring, which causes tech debt and current workloads to continue to drown the employees which put in the work. -- Remote workers are no longer aided in any way (You pay your own bills, no benefits to help) -- PTO is unlimited, but you will never get to use it because you are lucky if you even get your evenings and weekends off, much less a work day. -- Requirements are never provided, and the work is demanded on an arbitrary timeline that is never realistic. -- Story points are not story points but timesheet style hourly commitments. -- Team development? Not here, everyone has their own full sprints of hours and you are lucky if anyone is helping you or you helping others. -- Even if you are a rockstar, better than average reviews are extremely limited, if that, as a way for the company to cut costs. -- VERY UNEVEN DISTRIBUTION OF EQUITY FROM TOP DOWN

Review Title: Great place to work but must know how to adapt
Pros: - get to work with incredibly smart people - work life balance - employees are treated well, managers are caring - great product - high standards across the board. makes it a great place to work and easy to get stuff done - huge focus on growth and development; leaders invest in your career - unlimited PTO that you are actually encouraged to take (I take at least 4-5 weeks per year) - overall great benefits (Carrot fertility, mental health and personal coaching, affinity groups / ERGs, mentor programs, parental programs and benefits like backup care and parenting guidance, 5 months paid parental leave for both moms and dads)
Cons: - we are not the cheapest option for customers, which can lead to difficult conversations during renewals - some c-level managers can come off as out-of-touch - hypergrowth company means constant change, which can lead to burnout - no 401k match - if you're not in a main office, you miss out on a lot of benefits like free food, networking events, etc - D&I is hit or miss depending which org you're in

Pros: Freedom to excel how you want to
Cons: Growing pains of a growing company

Pros:
-Industry-leading product
-Smart/Hard-working people
-Good benefits/work environment
Cons: Internal systems (CRM, etc.) are pretty messy given all of the growth and disparate places that data lives

Pros:
1. Helpful peers
2. Good work culture
3. Leadership is always open to new ideas
Cons: Salary is a bit less for the amount of work done.

Review Title: Don't get foold by big name and sweet talks
Pros: work from home and name of firm
Cons: Internal politics which you will never able to understand on surface level

Review Title: Started great, then steadily declined in its culture
Pros: Smart people, competitive compensation, bi-weekly retrospectives on processes and team work, quarterly onsites, and interesting projects. There are still some great people working here, but there are also those who ruin it for everyone else, as you'll see in the cons section.
Cons:
While the company started out mostly great when I joined, many projects were not planned out correctly and resulted in gross underestimation, while churn relieved its original participants from any accountability. This only becomes apparent over time, but by the time one realizes the predicament they are in, they are too heavily invested and overworked to crawl out of it. Its famed culture started to decline soon after the arrival of several top level executives from Amazon, and once tech layoffs became fashionable, management blissfully declared that no layoffs were planned but instead "raised the bar" by vastly reducing the number of overperformers during each review cycle and enforced that 5% must be underperformers. Indeed, the culture continued its rapid descent while the company took on more and more former Amazon executives.

To be fair, promotions were rampant and many people who were not ready for their new roles were promoted too quickly to begin with. Perhaps this was seen as a way to combat the rapid rise, but did little to deal with people who were already in those roles; there were plenty of 'leaders' who are in no position to lead others. These people remained in positions of power while themselves underperformed, and are now pressured to deliver or streamline their costs. This resulted in making demands on their teams that started to overstep reasonable expectations, pushing those team members into the "underperform" category and finally managing them out with a performance improvement plan, despite performing well in every other metric, resulting in termination without severance. Culture, innovation, and work life balance now take a backseat at this company, but I suspect this is only the beginning.

Review Title: Query Team - Hard Time for Junior Engineers
Pros: - Vast majority of employees are extremely friendly and approachable. Everyone is knowledgeable and intelligent. - The work is interesting! The projects are very well thought out despite the problems being so difficult. - Code quality is mostly high. There's a lot of tech debt, but with time this will go away. This is a great company if you want to improve your C++ skills.
Cons: - Team choice is a coinflip. You can have a lead that is very available and will help you with career growth, or one that is invisible. Most leads are too busy with technical work to pay close enough attention to give feedback. Many junior engineers do not get any negative feedback unless they remind their lead many times. There are a few cases where promotions have been implied, but then at the last minute negative feedback is provided and no promotion is given. This is a hard situation to navigate for a junior engineer. - For the most productive engineers, bad behavior is ignored. These engineers are so knowledgeable and crucial to certain projects that consistently bad behavior is overlooked. They can be condescending and unapproachable with no repercussions. Many junior engineers avoid them, even though they are often the best person to ask questions. If you are on a team with one of these individuals and don't have another senior engineer to go to for questions, your career growth will be stunted. If you do ask them questions, they will give a bad performance review to your lead. Difficult situation for junior engineers.

Pros: Work life Balance, Good salary
Cons: Micro-manging , Too much hierarchy.

Pros: MongoDB is a highly reputable SaaS company and the C-suite knows what they are doing. You will learn a lot here. I can't speak highly enough of Dev Ittycheria the CEO, he is the real deal. Work culture is great, supporting a hybrid model (where remote work is allowed but in person is definitely encouraged in the hubs like HQ in NYC).
Cons: The Sales org runs the company, other business functions play second fiddle. Whiplash may arise when the sales leaders return from their annual offsite and present a new framework to the rest of the company. (but it's also a strength in that the Mongo sales team is probably in the top 5% tech sales cultures in the industry.) Where it can come into play is from a resourcing standpoint. Expect that if your team is not in Sales, you will run super lean. Secondly, as the company has become quite established (and big), many of the processes are fully built out. Depending on the org you are in, you may be more of an "operator" vs an "innovator". This comes down to personal preference on what you are looking for. But it definitely felt like a big company when I left, which wasn't the case when I joined.

Pros:
Tech forward
Nice people
Cool projects to work on
Cons: Huge, public company, so things can sometimes move slowly

Pros: Decent pay and some interesting code to write here and there. If you're a database person, the place could be good.
Cons: Snail pace of development. Their touted culture is nothing to be impressed by, I found it pretty lacking to say the least, nearly worst I've seen in my entire career. I didn't feel proud that I worked at MongoDB either. No regrets for leaving.

Pros: The product is great. Significant collaboration with account executives. They essentially bring in the customers. Some teams are better than the others. As an EM your job is to attach professional services to existing ongoing deals and see it through closure. Great pay. Good Benefits. Great work-life balance.
Cons: The scope of work in professional services engagement management team is pretty narrow. Role is limited to selling and not delivery. Not challenging enough. Too many supporting roles with very narrow breadth of responsibilities. This role can be eliminated completely, if they give training to Account executives or Solutions architects, or Consult engineers who actually deliver the work. Leadership is only focused on numbers and not their team. Very poor gender and diversity ratios. Very slow growth potential, especially if you are a person of color. Poor succession planning. Strangely enough the senior leadership keeps getting promoted, yet they keep doing the same job and nothing changes down the line. Poor feedback culture. Managers/Leaders will not help with personal growth. Huge dependency on account executives. Also, as soon as you join, the employee experience team will ask you to drop a review on glassdoor. Most reviews here are when people are in their very early days of employment, so take it with a pinch of salt.

Pros:
- Amazing company

Cons:

Review Title: Career progression + innovation-driven + massive future opportunity!
Pros: 1. Great product with massive future growth opportunity 2. Reward (pay, equity), recognize and promote high performers who drive impact across the company 3. Encourage experimentation and innovation (tech, Sales, Pre-Sales + Post-Sales approaches) 4. We challenge ourselves to be the best in the industry 5. Leadership - takes action on feedback provided in employee surveys and understands and respects people needs to manage work-life harmony (people are understanding of managing family life schedules & challenges) Personally, I've never progressed in my career faster, or learned more than in my career at MongoDB and I attribute a lot of that to the leadership that encourages and empowers us to "Think Big, Go Far" and "Make it Matter" (2 of our key values). For those who take ownership and initiative with their careers and have the tenacity and persistence to overcome challenges and adversity, there is huge opportunity.
Cons: 1. High pressure and highly demanding - tough to balance everything on our plates. 2. Significant effort and scrutiny on new investment spend (new hires, tools) (understandable with the focus on profitability) 3. More technical product sale - steeper learning curve for non-technical people

Pros: good company product and benefit
Cons: depends on which management team you are in

Review Title: Best Workplace in my whole career
Pros:
If you enjoy working in the tech industry and possess strong business acumen, MongoDB is the ideal workplace that consistently challenges you. There is always something new to learn, creating an environment that allows you to continuously develop and express yourself effectively. MongoDB boasts an excellent sales structure that adapts to the evolving demands of the industry. Notably, the management actively follows through on their commitments.

From the beginning, I've been impressed with the robust learning structure in place. It is an ongoing process that is essential for performing your job at its best. Moreover, there is ample support from the team and management to aid in your progress, allowing you to shape your career in the direction you prefer. MongoDB provides a dynamic and supportive work culture that encourages personal and professional growth.
Cons: Working at MongoDB is undeniably challenging, offering numerous opportunities to make a meaningful impact and leave your mark. While some may describe it as hard work, I believe it reflects the level of dedication required for optimal performance. Our consistent success quarter after quarter, as evidenced by MongoDB's financial statements, speaks to the effectiveness of this approach. It's a dynamic environment where hard work pays off and contributes to the company's ongoing success.

Review Title: Great place to start your career!
Pros:
Brilliant and amazing peers who are always ready to help.

Interesting and complex problems to tackle.

Review Title: Fast growing company with skilled engineers
Pros:
- MongoDB is growing a lot - it is well known by everyone in the technology industry
- I believe the product is unique (data developer platform, not just a DB)
- The company offers a great working model (hybrid, in-office, remote)
- It embraces lots of Amazonian cultures but at the same time it cares of employees similarly to companies like Google or Facebook 
- Recent joining of Jim Scharf (from AWS DDB) makes things ever more promising
- Engineering quality is good
Cons: - As the company grows fast, there are team and work processes that need improvement

Pros:
- Smart folks
- Great flexibility
- Great benefits / perks
Cons: - A bit of organized chaos still going on as the company continues to rapidly grow (this can be a pro or a con depending on your POV)

Pros:
Highly intelligent colleagues
Progressive, thoughtful leadership
Opportunities to grow skills, stretch yourself, etc.
Cons: Very very fast paced - not a con for everyone but may be for some

Pros: Great remote onboarding. They make an effort to ensure you get connected to everyone and understand the products.
Cons: Once you’re out of onboarding, get ready for the fire hose. And don’t expect to make grand process change. They are stuck in their inefficiency and seem fine with it. You’ll be too busy reminding people to review documents to spend time on problems that would create actual value. I’m surprised developers don’t completely run the place (maybe that would be better). There’s a cult mentality in the company. If you are a developer and / or a prior intern who started here and worked your way up, you’re tops. If you’re a program manager, there is a limit to how far you can grow here. The product team needs serious help and are not pulling their weight. Oh and whatever amazing culture they had being a scrappy company has been lost; Amazon execs took over C-Suite.

Pros:
Very good culture.
Great work to live balance.
Competitive pay.
Great people.
Excellent leadership.
Cons: Referral program is not ideal IMHO. It feels like referrals are not a priority. I do honest referrals for people I think would be great fits for the company and they are rarely interviewed. Mostly rejected by email or ghosted after weeks of silence. I would expect referrals to be contacted quickly either to reject them or to interview them.

Pros: free Food in the office, great culture, unlimited PTO, Great team to work with always available for you
Cons: no 401k match, hybrid role( but be discussed with your manager)

Review Title: A company that helps build your career
Pros: When I joined MongoDB, I was amazed by the employee-centric focus of the organization and the amazing leaders I had who really helped me guide and build a career in an Administrator Role. Thanks to their continuous support and freedom to explore options, I got my Salesforce Admin Certification, moved into the Sales Technology Administrator role, and continued my growth. Also, having an International team ranging from India to Europe to America increased my exposure, provided opportunities to learn about new cultures, and broadened my horizons.
Cons: A fast-paced company brings various challenges that require amazing skills to make an impact in your position and build an image for yourself.

Pros: Customer adoption that doesn't seem to be slowing down
Cons: Getting a bit "corporate" which is a hard pill to swallow for some.

Pros:
Immense growth opportunity.
A place to have a voice.
Cons: The company is still growing like a start-up so there are growing pains.

Review Title: A company that you would learn and experience at the same time.
Pros: It's been a year working in MongoDB. How time flies! I still remember the first day I join, it's the QBR week. I was impressed by the focus and dedication to the work of everyone. The whole team get together and spend quality time to talk and review the work. The leadership team will collect feedback and offer help to what's needed. That just me feel inspired and motivated. Along the year, the feeling still with me. I kept learning and adopt myself to the existing working environment. MongoDB also provide the best staff learning and development support. All new on board staff will need get trained with company background, product knowledge, and professional skills. Also lots of tools that we can leverage, the company grant the access to most of the popular tools in the market. MongoDB also have good package of employee benefit that also include children and partner. The company will have regular all hands meeting by the board, talk about all the things that staff cares and suggested. That's great to have as we are confidence by knowing what's going on inside and outside the company, and the impact it may be.
Cons: As the product is well known globally, the business expand to many regions. The cross functional/region collaboration is important and essential. Lots of meetings for alignment and planning. But we developed No Meeting Wednesday! :) And busy.

Pros: Good job and great product
Cons: Large team and manager by manager differences

Review Title: Rewarding, but challenging opportunity for Enterprise Sellers - a female's perspective
Pros: I felt compelled to write about my experience after reading some recent reviews from female sellers. I'd like to start off by saying that my intent is not to minimize anyone else's experience or condone biased behavior. If you have experienced discrimination because of your gender or for any other reason, that is wrong. With that said, I am a female who has been with MongoDB for 5 years in a variety of sales roles. I have personally felt incredibly supported throughout my time at this company. The sales teams here are top-notch and are full of talented people who I continue to learn from. Sales at MongoDB will challenge you, but it will also be rewarding. Don't get me wrong, there is no question that the number of men in sales outweighs the number of women. However, leadership has acknowledged the disparity and is seemingly putting in a genuine effort to bridge the gap. We have amazing affiliate groups like MDBWomen's Group and Sell Like a Girl which have created opportunities for females and allies to network and find mentors across MongoDB. I'm always humbled to see that senior leadership regularly participates in these events. I'm not sure what other company can say that their female CISO regularly attends affiliate group mentorship events - you're setting an amazing example, Lena. If you're a female in tech sales, I'd encourage you to consider MongoDB. Don't be afraid to ask questions and get a variety of different perspectives.
Cons: MongoDB is a challenging and complex sale. However, put the work in and trust the process.

Pros:
- Great colleagues
- You learn a lot in a short time and are thrown in the deep end
Cons: Always pushing for growth. Once a goal is reached, it feels like there isn't time taken to enjoy or savour this accomplishment. There is just a push from management for what the next goal is. This can lead to burn out, which I've seen across departments.
